Posts.Content: How awful. You've been suffering for a year and no one can help you. Terrible. If I were you, I'd find a new doctor and get a referral to someone trained in myofacial release therapy. It's worked wonders for others with your problems. You can Google it to find someone in your area. Also look up Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome. A significant number of women have it, so you are not alone. There are pain clinics that are trained in relieving that kind of pain. Another option to look into acupuncture. I've had it and it truly does work. You can get other opinions on one of my other discussion boards - www.breastcancer.org.
Posts.Title: Post mastectomy pain syndrome

Posts.Content:
I was well aware of the possibility of Post Mastectomy Pain Syndrome and discussed it at length with my breast surgeon as well as my plastic surgeon before my procedure. My anesthesiologist was aware of it too and said it's being studied more often now that more attention is being paid to breast cancer survivors. For so long many of us didn't live long enough. Now that medicine is keeping us alive longer, we are demanding that our quality of life issues be addressed. 
Research this on REPUTABLE websites like MD Anderson, Johns Hopkins, and Mayo Clinic. There is a lot of info about
 it and what doctors are doing to prevent it and treat it.
Posts.Title: Post mastectomy pain syndrome

Posts.Content: Trace,
Posts.Title: Burning sensation and pain in left breast

Posts.Content: Oh dear, so sorry you are going through all this. At least it has moved fast. Some women report months of agonizing waiting for every step. I have no personal experience withÂ a radical scar but have read posts from others on the breastcancer.org forum.
Posts.Title: Radial scar.... anyone else have?

Posts.Content:
I had it 6 months ago. It sounds worse than it is. It doesn't hurt and the hardest part for me was trying to get comfortable before they started. They let me shift around a bunch until I was sure I was in a position that I could deal with for about
 an hour. If you can take in an iPod with headphones, it will help distract you and pass the time. You'll be staring at the wall for a long time and listening to the doc and nurses below you exchange info and numbers that make no sense. That was a little unnerving because you don't know what is happening. (I hadn't talked to anyone who'd had it before I did so my imagination was running wild.)
They give you a little shot of lidocaine which stings for a second. No big deal at all. They make a tiny incision and give you another anesthetic that will numb your whole breast for the rest of the day. After that you will hear the noise of the equipment whirring or compressing, but you don't feel a thing. Really. 
Once they are finished taking the samples (I had 20 taken) they put in a tiny titanium marker. Since the majority of biopsies are benign, it will show up on subsequent mammograms or MRI's so they will know exactly where the biopsy was done the previous year. Also if you have a lumpectomy, the marker guides them to the right place. You don't feel the marker and it doesn't prevent you from going through airport security or prevent you from having MRI's, etc. 
When they are finished, they put a steri strip over the little cut and you go to another room for a regular mammogram to make sure the titanium clip shows up correctly. That's it. Takes about
 an hour start to finish. May be less if you don't have as many samples taken.
After the numbing medicine wore off that night, the breast felt achy. I took some Tylenol and it was gone the next day. A week later I went back to have them check the little cut. I had a small bruise and a little tiny blister there. No big deal. No discomfort. The cut had healed already. I got a Band-Aid and left.
Good luck!
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Core Biopsy

Posts.Content:
Debdidit,
If I were in your situation, I wouldn't do ANY more reconstruction for now. Those tissue expanders can wait. Get your body healed first and have some down time from all this chaos. I saw my plastic surgeon yesterday to discuss my fourth surgery (next month) and he said the failure and complication rate goes way down if you let your body stabilize for a while. He had me wait for two months after #3 to even talk to me about
 surgery #4 and now there will be another month wait til he does it. I want him to combine two repairs (muscles and pocket work) in the same area into one surgery so I don't have to have a #5, but he is reluctant and will only say he will "consider" it. With a history of infection, he said he would rather not have more than one area of incisions. That will obviously reduce the chances of another infection, but not eliminate it. Of course, having general anesthesia again is not without complications either. I hate it that cancer takes away our choices.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy complications

Posts.Content:
You have certainly been through enough for ten women, much less one. No doubt it will get better, but when you are in the middle of it and don't see anything but more disappointment and pain, it's nearly impossible to keep your chin up. Do you have someone you can talk to? I would think that is a major priority for you. It's well known that your frame of mind can affect your healing capabilities. 
I can understand a bit of your situation because I also had complications after BMX and immediate placement of implants. I developed an infection on post op day one that would not respond to antibiotics until the 3rd change. A lot of damage had already been done but the new antibiotic stopped the infection and reversed some pending necrosis. On day 14 I went back to surgery and they removed the tissue, skin, and parts of three muscles under my left arm and on the side of the left implant. The implant was removed since there was no longer enough good skin to cover it, and a tissue expander was put in. After three months of saline injections and pain to expand the skin and another month of waiting, the tissue expander was exchanged for a smaller implant. The implant on the other side was now twice as big, so that side had to be reconstructed. I am 5 weeks out from that 3rd surgery with 2 more repair surgeries to come. I have a lot of nerve damage from 3 surgeries in 4 1/2 months. I have to have a surgery to repair my underarm and side, and another one to try to repair the muscles that prevent movement from the top of my former breast to my shoulder.
Breast cancer certainly isn't for sissies, is it?
I have read about
 the many problems smokers have with healing and know that some doctors want the patient to be at least six months smoke-free before they will do surgery. Does you doctor feel that had a part in the failure of your surgeries? Good luck to you and stay in touch.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy complications

Posts.Content:
You are coping great for someone who has had all the problems you've had. I don't understand why the doctor is so reluctant to relieve your pain. Other people who've had big surgeries are in la-la land with Percocet, Oxycodone, etc. Oh well, you tried. I'm fatally allergic to narcotics and have coded 4 times when doctors (twice in an ER, once in the cardiac unit, and once in the operating room) gave me something that is "so mild, you won't have a problem with THIS. "Wrong! Sometimes I wonder what they really know about
 pain relief and how much they are taught in med school. I do know that more and more people are going to pain clinics and turning to non-traditional medicine.
Although many people don't believe in it, I've had excellent results with acupuncture. It really works but it's a cumulative thing, over a week or so. My mother was a nurse in an internal medicine practice. They hired a Chinese doctor and my mother did not approve because of what she'd been taught. After seeing people being helped, she had to admit there must be something to it. She ended up quitting and going to work for Dr. Ho when he set up his own practice. I had elbow tendonitis that did not respond to any kind of treatment for a year. I saw Dr. Ho for a week and voila - no tendonitis. It never came back. Many doctors are using acupuncture for pain now. Maybe it would help you.
Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content: We know just how you feel. We've ALL been there. It's so easy for other people to say it's going to be alright. And all those statistics don't mean much when you are worried. This is the hardest part. Waiting is the WORST.
Posts.Title: Waiting for mammogram

Posts.Content:
Hi Mike,
Yes, I'm sure you are right about
 age playing a big role in the decision. Also 12 years ago was equivalent to the Stone Age in breast cancer research and treatment. I had the BMX with immediate reconstruction with saline implants and woke up with the nice perky breasts of a 20 year old! It's a "one and done" operation. I knew from previous surgeries that it would be really hard to recover from an operation on my abdomen and adding surgery on my chest and pectoral muscles would make it difficult to even get out of bed, much less walk the halls, go to the bathroom, etc. Recovery at home would be harder as well. There didn't seem to be any point going through that when a safe saline implant would work fine. 
I was not at all attached to having breasts. They had nourished three children and I didn't need them anymore. Plus, why would I save any part of them...they were trying to kill me!
Posts.Title: 2mm Lobular Carcinoma found after breast reduction

Posts.Content: Patsy, this is not an emergency so you are just going to spend hours and $ in order to be brushed off again. Can you find another doctor who can see you before April? Breast cancer is not an emergency. It grows very very slowly...sometimes for years...before it can be detected. Most lumps are benign.
Posts.Title: Found a lump in my breast.. Doctor is blowing me off

Posts.Content: Skin grafts can work wonders. So can the right drugs. Hang in there. I can also recommend another website, breastcancer.org, where you can find thousands of women, some of whom have had your experiences.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy complications

Posts.Content:
KAC, congratulations on your wonderful news! Glad you are going for mammograms more frequently since you have breast cancer in your family. Have you considered having the BRCA1 & BRCA2 test? It will tell you if you have the gene that increases your chances of developing breast cancer about
 50%.
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content: You sound like you have a good head on your shoulders and aren't likely to make a decision without researching it through and through. Good for you. That's the way I am too. Knowledge is power. It reduces unfounded worry but can also to lead to the syndrome where you know "just enough to be dangerous." I make lists of questions based on my research and ask my doctors. They seem to appreciate that I've done my homework and never mind my questions.
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content:
Kaz62,
We've been in your shoes and certainly understand like no one else could. I've never heard it said that it was common to get a call back after your first mammogram. The mammo you are going to get next week will focus on a certain area and magnify it a bit so the radiologist can see it easier. The vast majority of people who get called back never have a biopsy. If you do have to have a biopsy, it's truly no big deal, not painful, just nerve wracking. Biopsies are negative the majority of the time. 
You may also be asked to have an ultrasound or a MRI. They are just trying to make sure everything is ok. Those darned calcifications we women get as we grow older can be confused with early stage, non-invasive DCIS so look at your call back as a good thing. If it IS something, they will find it very early. Better than having a radiologist who is sloppy and doesn't bother following up. That happens. 
I got called back at about
 your age because of calcifications. The magnification mammo proved it was nothing. They compare your next year's mammo to this one you just had so they don't call you back again unless they see something new. It was ten years before I got a call back again because the calcifications increased in a normal way. This year there were changes so I got called back. 
The radiologist report will have a BI-RADS score, 1 thru 6, which is their recommendation for whether or not you should have a biopsy. The BI-RADS score doesn't mean you have cancer, and being sent for a biopsy doesn't mean they expect to find cancer. You might just have dense breasts that are hard to diagnose. Your doctor or the radiologist will explain all this to you. 
Be worried, be concerned, but don't panic. It's too early. The vast majority of women who get a call back do not have cancer. The vast majority who are sent for a biopsy do not have cancer. Breathe. Keep in touch and let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content: Oops, forgot to add that when the pathology report came back after the double mastectomy, it showed that the "good side" had cancer too! It had been missed, even by an MRI done before surgery to look for any other areas of concern. It was LCIS, which apparently is harder to diagnose by mammogram. I saw an oncologist earlier this week for the first time. She confirmed what my surgeon said...no radiation or chemo would be required. No hormone therapy would be needed. They got it all. My lymph nodes were clear. It hadn't spread. They got it early. My husband cannot stop smiling. This nightmare is over for both of us. Unfortunately not every journey ends like mine but I know you will be there every step of the way for your wife. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Lump found during mammogram

Posts.Content:
The extra protein is wonderful for increasing your healing power. 
No one knows why we get breast cancer. It's not from eating or not eating certain foods. If it was that easy or obvious, doctors would be shouting the "cure" from the roof tops. There is no cure for breast cancer. The best we can do is to be NED - No Evidence of Disease. Some people call it remission. So it cannot hurt to eat better. You'll feel better. But it's not going to keep you from getting a recurrence of breast cancer.
Posts.Title: "Healthy Diet" for breast cancer?

Posts.Content:
Ramman,
I know you are worried. My husband seemed to take my diagnosis harder than I did. In the 2 months since then, he has been with me at every appointment and procedure. 
Breast cancer is usually not painful. It's a good thing you have a follow up planned. Breasts develop calcifications as we age - it's normal. On a mammogram, they are usually tiny bright white round "pearls" scattered around the breast. Radiologists look for calcifications that are oddly shaped or close together. They compare current and previous mammograms as well. Many women have quite dense breast tissue which makes it harder to see these changes. 
Most of the time when they see something that isn't clear to them, they ask for a second mammogram that will magnify the area of concern. Ultrasounds are not as commonly used but are certainly helpful. Most women will have a biopsy next. Today a stereotactic breast biopsy is done. They give you a little lidocaine that stings a minute, but that's it. I found it completely painless. The incision is tiny, 1/3", and closed with a steri strip. I had 12 areas of concern in one area so they took 12 tiny samples and found cancer is 8 of them. That means that 4 areas had no cancer at all even though they looked like the other ones. That's why they need the biopsy...to make sure. Lot's of women have a completely negative biopsy and your wife could be one of those.
The pathologist will check the biopsy samples and if they find cancer, they will identify the kind and stage of development. Mine was small and confined to a duct in my breast, DCIS, stage 0, but identified as an aggressive type. The usual treatment for that kind of cancer if a lumpectomy, where they take out the tumor and some adjacent tissue, followed by radiation. Chemotherapy might be added. She will likely be given hormone therapy, Tamoxifen, for 5 years afterwards. All that sounded awful to me, so I chose a mastectomy. No radiation or chemo would be needed. I took it one step further by choosing to have the other breast removed as well. I decided I didn't want to deal with worry that the cancer would come back or show up in the other breast. 
I also chose immediate reconstruction which was done via by a plastic surgeon right after the general surgeon was finished with the double mastectomy. Implants were placed. Not all women are candidates for this and have tissue expanders placed instead. Weekly saline injections slowly expand the tissue so it can accommodate an implant a few months later. 
Some women do not want to lose their breast so they would never make the same decision as I did. There is no right or wrong. Every woman is different. Let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Lump found during mammogram

Posts.Content:
Carol, from what I've read, Tamoxifen is not for post-menopausal women. It is useless after menopause because it attaches to estrogen and progesterone. And Diquilter, I believe tamoxifen is not chemo but is hormone therapy for ER+ and PR+ pre-menopausal women that reduces the chances of a reoccurrence. I've read on the MD Anderson website that doctors are recommending young women stay on it for 10 years now instead of 5. Most of the under 50 women I know are on it. 
Carol, since Tamoxifen is ineffective for you now (plus is causing so many side effects) I would ask your doctor why he doesn't switch you to aromatase inhibitors that are usually given to post menopausal women.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen, is it really needed after bilateral mastectomies

Posts.Content: There is no point being worried like this. You'll fall apart and it might be absolutely nothing. You have to see a doctor soon.
Posts.Title: I'm in quite a bit of pain

Posts.Content: Quite a few men have breast cancer. I correspond with one man now on Cancer Survivors Network and there are others on Breast Cancer.org. It will help you to be in touch with other men in your situation.
Posts.Title: I feel like a stranger

Posts.Content: Sure, most of us have gone through the same thing. Most of the time, even with a biopsy, it turns out to be one of the benign breast conditions. The lump may still need to be removed, but it isn't cancer. The fact that you have a family history makes you more afraid but most women whose 1st degree relatives had breast cancer, do not get it. It does increase your chances, however, so it's good that you are getting the biopsy. Keep us informed.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Keep in touch. We are here for you. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Lytic Lesion Humerus

Posts.Content: KAC,
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content:
The BRCA 1 BRCA 2 test is expensive - about
 $3,000 - and there is no point having it unless you are prepared to do something if it turns out positive. If you have the gene, will you have a double mastectomy so you will never get breast cancer? Will you have your ovaries removed? If not, will you worry,Â knowing that everyone who has the geneÂ DOES NOT get breast or ovarian cancer...but a lot do? It's a very personal decision.
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content: Girl, find another doctor! It doesn't matter if the one you have is not concerned...YOU are concerned and need help.
Posts.Title: breast itching

Posts.Content: The doc sent you to the hospital? What did they do? I'm not sure I know what you mean by expecting to have the triple three test. They didn't do a mammogram? You have to wait three weeks for what procedure?
Posts.Title: I'll be grey ....... By the time I get my tests

Posts.Content: So glad your surgery is over. Looking forward to hearing how you are doing.
Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
Can you delay the rads a few days until you figure out what's going on with your red breasts? That just isn't normal. Your skin should not be changing colors. Can you get a second opinion?
As far a bras go, I don't wear one. I woke from all three surgeries in a bra that was front zip and held gauze pads against the incisions. Once I left the hospital, I never wore a bra again. I wore very loose tops and pinned my drains to my jeans or put them in my pockets. I can't imagine wearing a bra with the pain you are having. My PS says while doctors have their own preferences, there is no medical fact that a bra is needed UNLESS you are doing exercise that will make you bounce. He does say, however, that if you feel better wearing a bra, do it. Just no underwires. He thinks a sports bra is all you might ever need.
Posts.Title: Question about bras/clothing after surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear of your diagnosis. I cannot offer any info on BC + arthritis but hopefully someone else will. If you don't hear anything, come over to breastcancer.org. There are active thread on there with woman who have similar challenges.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Breast Cancer and RA

Posts.Content: Go see a neurologist! Something is WRONG. Good luck.
Posts.Title: chest pain,anxiety,stress something?

Posts.Content:
Hi Mike,
My husband is also a Mike and has had prostate cancer 5 years. He has PSA's every 6 months and gets a biopsy every year. So far, so good. It's still there but is not growing. No surgery planned.
I got diagnosed with DCIS breast cancer July 18th and had a double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction August 23rd. Prior to surgery I had 2 mammograms and an MRI with contrast to make sure there was no cancer in the other breast. None was found but I wanted the bilateral MX anyway. Imagine my surprise when the pathology report showed cancer in the "good side" too! It was a different kind, LCIS, but more concerning because of the link to other kinds of cancer. I've since learned that LCIS is harder to diagnose in dense breasts but it still amazes me they missed it completely. Unfortunately I've talked to many more women lately who've had the same experience. 
The oncologist said I had made the right decision and that no chemo or rads or hormone therapy would be needed since the cancer was caught and removed before it became invasive & sentinel node biopsy showed no lymph involvement.
I don't understand why women with cancer that is not yet invasive go through a lumpectomy (often a re-excision as well), 7 weeks of radiation 5 days a week, and 5 years of Tamoxifen, all the while crossing their fingers that it won't come back or show up in the other breast. With a double mastectomy, it's over and done. No further treatment. 
DCIS cannot grow in the tiny bit of breast tissue that might remain because that tiny bit doesn't contain a duct. LCIS can't grow because there are no more lobules. Doesn't mean you don't have a tiny change (1-2%) of some other kind of cancer showing up in the bit of tissue, but it won't be IDC or LDC or a recurrence of DCIS or LCIS.
Posts.Title: 2mm Lobular Carcinoma found after breast reduction

Posts.Content:
New here - sorry I didn't come earlier so I could reassure anyone who is going to get a stereotactic breast biopsy that it is nothing to be afraid of. Mine was painless and over in less than an hour. The table has an 
opening for your breast and is raised so the doctor and nurses can work below you. They give you a quick little shot of lidocaine which only stings for a second. You don't feel the little incision later (mine was about
 1/2") or the second anesthetic they give you to numb your whole breast. (Honestly, I didn't feel a thing.) You don't feel the compression. You can hear the machine below you whirring and the doc/nurses talking to each other. They took 12 samples during mine. They put in a titanium clip so they can find the exact area again. Then they put a couple of steri strips on you and a Band-Aid. You get up and go into another room for a mammogram so they can make sure they got everything they intended to. That's it!
Posts.Title: Terrified... Stereotactic Breast Biopsy

Posts.Content:
Pay no attention to the negative stories. Honestly, it is NOTHING. I would tell you if there was anything to be concerned about
. There ISN'T. A mammogram can be painful but this is absolutely nothing like that. You won't feel a thing. The table looks different because it has 
openings for your breast to drop down and it raises up and down like a hospital bed. The hardest part for me was getting comfortable on my belly and being still for an hour! LOL. 
After you are settled, you will get one little sting of lidocaine just below the skin...only lasts a few seconds. Mine was given on the outside of my breast nearest my arm because the area of concern was deep, near my chest wall. Yours will depend on which part of your breast they need to look at. That's the last thing you will feel. After you are numb on that little patch of skin, they will put in another kind of numbing medication that numbs the entire breast for several hours and make a TINY cut in the skin - mine wasÂ less than 1/2" at most. You don't even know it's happening. You will hear the equipment moving and the doctor and nurse speaking to each other about
 positioning it. They biopsied 12 places on me. They will place a little marker in the area they biopsied and it's over. I had aÂ two steri-strips over the cut and a bandage that stayed until the next week when I went back to have them check it and get the results. That night after the numbing wore off, I took some Tylenol because my breast felt a little achy down deep.Â 
There is absolutely nothing to be scared of. You could take some ear buds and listen to music during the hour they are working. That will help you relax and pass the time.
Posts.Title: Terrified... Stereotactic Breast Biopsy

Posts.Content: Since your mother died of breast cancer, it's understandable that you are so worried. I've never heard anyone mention the symptoms you report as a marker for breast cancer, so that's in your favor. Many of us never had a lump so unfortunately that doesn't mean anything. There are different kinds of breast cancer. How old are you? The pins and needles sounds like it involves a nerve. The pulling feeling across your breast sounds like muscles are involved. If there is something going on with your muscles, that could have affected some of the nerves that are in the same area. Have you had a mammogram?
Posts.Title: Lytic Lesion Humerus

Posts.Content: KAC,
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content: CHH,
Posts.Title: Mammogram callback

Posts.Content: Breast tissue changes over the years. A radiologist can estimate your age based on a mammogram. If you have talked to your doctor and he isn't concerned, you have two choices: accept it as a normal part of YOUR aging process, or see another doctor.
Posts.Title: Pain during ovulation

Posts.Content: No personal experience. I do know that if it is under 18, it is called low and no chemo is given. I had DCIS and my breast surgeon said Onco was not needed since I was having a bilateral mastectomy. Wish I'd had it tho.
Posts.Title: OncoTypeDX

Posts.Content: Merrida, make sure they give you a cream called Emla on your areola before the sentinel node biopsy. It helps to dull the pain a little bit. You said you are having precancerous tissue removed. What do you mean?
Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
Merrida,
You put it very well. When men get scared they can't admit it and show it in other ways. The fact that he feels relieved and secure enough to write down his feelings in a public way is wonderful. My husband is a retired Air Force pilot and Colonel. He's used to being in charge and being able to fix whatever issue comes up. Well that didn't work so well this year and he was quite scared. He chose to stick by my side for everything, ask questions, research, and accompany me to every appointment and treatment. He's gotten a bit compulsive at times, but I don't mind. Everyone has to cope in their own way.
Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
Mike,
LOL. Sorry to say it, but you get NO VOTE when it comes to the size of her chest! If I had it to do again, I would be even smaller than I am now. I'm the one who has to live with it so I should get to decide. Both my husband and plastic surgeon said I should go with a D implant and it didn't matter one way or the other to me prior to surgery because I was still in a fog from the diagnosis, so I didn't disagree. I think they are too big, but really, compared to what I was before - ridiculously huge FFF's, everything is small. I like little foobs. (The aren't breasts anymore...those are gone. These are fake boobs - foobs.) I love not having to wear a bra after 50 years!
Posts.Title: 2mm Lobular Carcinoma found after breast reduction

Posts.Content: With your family history, of course you are worried. I would be too. The fact is, however, that most lumps are not cancer so the odds are on your side. Good thing you are getting that mammogram so soon. Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Found odd shaped lump...

Posts.Content:
Sounds like you are getting yourself in some kind of weird position while you are sleeping. Burning pain tells me it's nerve related. The fact that it goes away means when you get out of that position, there is no more nerve compression. 
Figure out a way to block yourself in with pillows so you can't easily get into an odd position.
Posts.Title: Breast pain only at night

Posts.Content: April 7th is fine. It will be hard to wait but nothing earth shattering will happen in such a short time. If you had symptoms of one of the aggressive cancers it would be different, but you don't, so you can relax a little. Your doctor is wrong...young women do get breast cancer...just not as often. It's statistically more likely in women over 60, so it's not the first thing doctors look for in someone your age. The family history you state is not a factor. The only family history that counts is a first degree relative- mother, father, sister, brother. Having other relatives with breast cancer does not affect your chances. However, you don't have to have any cancer history in your family in order to be diagnosed. (I had none, but my daughters will now have a first degree relative to add to their chances.) Women's breasts go through tremendous changes at certain points of their lives and lumps, bumps, and soreness are common in your 20's. (Particularly when you are having changes in your monthly cycles.) Your doctor may be right but since you are getting so upset, he should order a screening mammogram, not an ultrasound. They are not routinely offered to women under 40 in the U.S. and sometimes insurance companies won't pay for them before then, but they aren't all that expensive so you could pay for it yourself if you need to. There are organizations online that offer reduced cost or free mammograms. Google and see what is in your area. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Found a lump in my breast.. Doctor is blowing me off

Posts.Content:
Don't tell ANYONE until you are sure. If you do, and it turns out to be something else, you'll never hear the end of it! You don't have long to wait so vent to us and share your concerns here. We'll help you wait.
Did you have a mammogram? That's usually the first step. Often there are two mammograms, one to screen and one to magnify the area to see if a biopsy is needed. 
The vast majority of breast lumps are not cancer. There are a number of benign conditions that can cause them including cysts that can be fluid filled. I've read a hundred stories like yours lately. The odds are definitely on your side. Stay in touch. Thinking of you.
Posts.Title: Please help. Found lump. Am terrified!!!

Posts.Content:
Ask your doc to order the Emla cream. You want the area numb if possible. I was sent downstairs to radiology for the injections about
 2 hours before my double mastectomy. It takes that long for the radioactivity to reach the sentinel nodes. They use a Geiger counter in the OR during the surgery to find the sentinel nodes. Some people have the procedure the day before surgery or even a week before but that means another incision or two. I'm glad I had mine the same day as my surgery.
I had two radiologists do the injections of radioisotopes. They do two on each side. The doctors counted down 3,2,1 to make sure they were doing it at the same time. Radioisotopes have a different Ph than your body, so it hurts when injected. Have the docs massage the area right away...that helps a lot. Expect a Texas-size bee sting.
Posts.Title: New to BC, surgery tomorrow, intro

Posts.Content:
Usually they will call you back in for a diagnostic mammogram if your screening mammogram shows anything suspicious. The diagnostic mammogram may show an area of concern that the radiologist will give a rating to. It's radiologist talk for "get a biopsy" or "everything looks good, no need for biopsy" and everything in between. The report will say Birads 1 through 6 and will point out some characteristics that are concerning - or not. 
Then they will do a biopsy to confirm one way or the other. It takes about
 a week to get your results.
Posts.Title: Found odd shaped lump...

Posts.Content:
Oh dear, now I understand. How frustrating to have to wait three weeks. It will all work out in the end, however, if they do a mammogram, a scan (MRI or ultrasound?), and a biopsy. (Did they tell you what kind of biopsy? There are several different kinds.) Usually we only get one of those at a time and we have to wait weeks in between them, so you'll be ahead in the long run and will know for sure. When you only get a mammogram and then have to wait for another test, your mind go crazy. They can tell you fairly quickly after the mammogram if there is anything unusual if there is a radiologist on staff. Surely there is one at a hospital. The biopsy results take a few days. I think I had to wait about
 a week. Keep in touch and let us know how it's going.
Posts.Title: I'll be grey ....... By the time I get my tests

Posts.Content: That's great news! Loved how you described your experience. It will be helpful to others I'm sure.
Posts.Title: Biopsy scare... this forum gave me peace of mind

Posts.Content:
How old are you? As we age, breasts develop calcifications. Radiologists know how to differentiate the normal ones from the suspicious ones. If there is anything that could possibly be abnormal, they call you back in for a magnification mammogram. Some skip straight to a biopsy. I had calcifications about
 10 years ago and was called back for magnified mammo. The radiologist was great and took me into his office to show me what they found and why it was not suspicious anymore. (Normal calcifications look like scattered bright white round tiny pearls. Suspicious areas have clusters of rice-like or branched bright white spots.) Two months ago it happened again but this time it wasn't good news. I had a stereotactic biopsy (painless by the way) and got the results a few days later. They found it early however. It was an aggressive grade so I had a double mastectomy 5 weeks ago.
Posts.Title: Second call to come in Scare

Posts.Content:
With your family history, you have every right to be concerned. However, at your age you have microcalcifications throughout your breasts. We all do as we get older. The radiologist has probably found some that aren't nice and round or some that are close together. They will do a second mammogram which will focus on the area of concern. Then the radiologist will give you a BI RAD score (0 - 5) which represents his recommendation of whether or not you should have a biopsy. Most women who have biopsies do not have breast cancer. Look at the topic above this one where I have talked to someone else who was concerned. I have detailed what a biopsy is like. Once you have all the details, you can make a decision about
 what you want to do. My cancer (DCIS) was caught early before it had spread to any adjacent breast tissue but was an aggressive sort. I decided on a double mastectomy because I could not worry the rest of my life if a lumpectomy had gotten it all, would it come back, or would it spread to the other breast. Peace of mind was most important to me. The normal treatment is a lumpectomy with radiation. Once I investigated radiation, I knew it wasn't for me either. Luckily my oncologist told me last week they had gotten it all, it would not be able to return because all the ducts and lobules are gone, and that I would definitely not have to have radiation or chemo or hormone therapy. By the way, the pathology report from the mastectomy on the "good" side showed cancer there too - a different kind, but small. It had been missed on mammogram and a bilateral MRI with contrast done before surgery to make sure there was no more cancer hiding anywhere in either breast. I made the right decision for me. Treatment for breast cancer has improved by leaps and bounds in the past two years. Even if you have it, it is no longer a death sentence. Good luck. Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Worried of finding bc

Posts.Content:
Of course you are frightened. We've all been in your shoes so we know exactly how you feel. My cancer was also diagnosed in a routine mammogram. Don't worry about
 size. 17 mm is 1.7 centimeters, which is how most tumors are measured. That's not very big... just a little over 1/2 inch. If it does turn out to be cancer, sounds like they see it early. What kind of doc called you back?Â  Since you don't usually make appointments with a radiologist, I'm think this was some other kind of doctor. If it was a radiologist it would be more significant.
Posts.Title: Mammogram callback
